column27: Description

column1: Add Quick Start UI Modal for Career Canvas Initialization
column27:
Add a new Quick Start UI Modal that guides users through the initial setup of Career Canvas.
The modal should allow users to set up a custom profile or explore example profiles (e.g., Marcus Thompson, Dr. Sarah Chen, Jamie Rodriguez).
Include fields for name, profession/current role, career goal, email, and LinkedIn URL, along with an option to request a Cleansheet experimental profile.
Display consent and privacy details, ensuring users understand all data is stored locally in the browser.
Conclude with a *“*Start Building My Career Canvas*”* action to launch the workspace.



!image-20251107-105651.png|width=583,alt="image-20251107-105651.png"!

column1: Add Onboarding Tour UI to Cleansheet Canvas Dashboard
column27:
* Implement a guided onboarding tour feature in the *Cleansheet* dashboard to help new users understand the platform’s key functionalities. This tour will provide a step-by-step walkthrough of essential sections such as *Career Experience, Goals, Portfolio, and Interview Prep*.
* The tour should display an interactive modal with navigation options like *Next*, *Previous*, and *Skip Tour*, as shown in the attached screenshot. The UI must align with the existing Cleansheet theme clean, modern, and minimalistic using consistent color schemes, typography, and spacing.
* Each step should highlight a specific section or feature on the screen with a tooltip or spotlight effect, accompanied by descriptive text guiding the user on that feature’s purpose.




!image-20251107-105217.png|width=686,alt="image-20251107-105217.png"!

This includes:

* *Right slideout content redesign* for all nodes.
* Updated visual layout and styling across all node types.current.
* Streamlined node interaction experience for better consistency and usability.

column1: Move Atlas code to Cleansheet repo
column27: A merged code base between Atlas and Cleansheet
Implementation of Atlas leveraging Azure Blobs and Postgres as a service in the Cleansheet Azure Account.

column1: Validate invitee as registered user on Enter key press instead of on Send Invitation button
column27:
Currently, when inviting a user (by username), the system only checks if the invitee is a registered user *after* clicking the *Send Invitation* button. This causes unnecessary delay and a poor user experience.
The validation should instead occur *immediately when the user presses Enter*, showing an error if the invitee does not exist in the system  before  allowing the Send Invitation action.

column1: Add auto-suggested username on Register screen (editable)
column27: When a user opens the Register screen, auto-suggest a username (derived from their email) and pre-fill it in the username field. The suggested username must be editable. The user can change it before submitting. Ensure validation messages and uniqueness checks work the same as for manually entered usernames.

column1: Implement Audit Log to Azure Blob

column27:
* Shared structures will now *appear in the "Shared With Me" tab* instead of being sent via email.
* *Invitee can delete* a shared structure from *their own workspace* without affecting the *owner's workspace*.
* If the *owner deletes* a shared structure, it will be *deleted for both the owner and the invitee*.
* When a *collaborator is removed*, display the message:
_"You are no longer a collaborator on this structure."_
As a user, I do not expect that my email username is case sensitive.

h1. Atlas Platform Audit Logging Requirement

*Document ID:* REQ-ATLAS-AUDIT-001
*Version:* 1.0
*Date:* 2025-09-24
*Status:* Draft
*Classification:* Internal

h2. 1. Overview

h3. 1.1 Purpose

This requirement defines the specifications for comprehensive audit logging capabilities specifically for the Atlas platform component within the Cleansheet ecosystem. The audit logging system shall capture, store, and provide access to security-relevant events and user activities within Atlas platform operations.

h3. 1.2 Scope

This requirement covers:

* Atlas platform user authentication and authorization events
* Data access and modification activities within Atlas
* Administrative actions performed on Atlas platform
* System configuration changes specific to Atlas
* Integration events between Atlas and other Cleansheet components
* API access and usage patterns for Atlas services
* Local audit log collection, encryption, and transmission to Azure Storage
* Configuration management for Azure storage connection parameters

*Out of Scope:*

* Audit logging for other Cleansheet platform components (Corpus, Learner Profiles, anything residing in Azure Tables/Storage)
* Performance monitoring logs
* Debug or diagnostic logging
* Business intelligence or analytics logging
* Log analysis, alerting, or reporting capabilities
* Long-term retention management beyond transmission to Azure

h3. 1.3 Business Justification

* *Compliance:* Meet regulatory requirements for educational technology platforms
* *Security:* Provide audit trail data for external security monitoring systems
* *Accountability:* Ensure all Atlas platform activities are logged to external storage
* *Data Integrity:* Maintain tamper-proof audit records in Azure immutable storage
* *Operational Simplicity:* Minimize local storage requirements and management overhead

h2. 2. Functional Requirements

h3. 2.1 Event Capture

The Atlas audit logging system shall capture the following event categories:

h4. 2.1.1 Authentication Events

* User login attempts (successful/failed)
* Password changes and resets
* Multi-factor authentication events
* Session creation, expiration, and termination
* Service account authentication

h4. 2.1.2 Authorization Events

* Permission grants and revocations
* Role assignments and modifications
* Access control policy changes
* Privilege escalation attempts

h4. 2.1.3 Data Access Events

* Atlas Canvas content access (view, edit, create, delete)
* File uploads and downloads
* Search queries and results
* Export operations
* Collaboration activities

h4. 2.1.4 Administrative Events

* User account creation, modification, deletion
* System configuration changes
* Feature flag modifications
* Maintenance mode activation/deactivation
* Backup and restore operations

h4. 2.1.5 Integration Events

* API calls to/from Atlas platform
* External system connections
* Data synchronization events
* Webhook executions

h3. 2.2 Event Data Structure

Each audit log entry shall include:

{code:json}{
  "eventId": "uuid",
  "timestamp": "ISO 8601 datetime",
  "platform": "atlas",
  "eventType": "authentication|authorization|data_access|administrative|integration",
  "eventCategory": "specific_category",
  "userId": "user_identifier",
  "sessionId": "session_identifier",
  "sourceIp": "ip_address",
  "userAgent": "browser/client_info",
  "resource": "affected_resource_identifier",
  "action": "action_performed",
  "result": "success|failure|partial",
  "severity": "low|medium|high|critical",
  "details": {
    "additional_context": "value",
    "before_state": "previous_value",
    "after_state": "new_value"
  },
  "correlationId": "request_correlation_id"
}{code}

h3. 2.3 Local Storage and Azure Transmission

h4. 2.3.1 Local Storage Requirements

* *Temporary Storage:* Logs retained locally only until successfully transmitted to Azure
* *Immediate Deletion:* Local audit logs deleted immediately after confirmed Azure receipt
* *Encryption:* All local audit data encrypted using AES-256 before storage
* *Queue Management:* Failed transmission logs queued for retry with exponential backoff
* *Storage Limit:* Maximum 48 hours of audit data retained locally during extended Azure disconnection

h4. 2.3.2 Azure Storage Configuration

*Recommended Storage Solution:* Azure Blob Storage with Immutable Storage Policies

*Rationale for Blob Storage over Tables:*

* *Immutability:* Native support for Write-Once-Read-Many (WORM) policies
* *Cost Efficiency:* Lower cost for write-heavy audit logging workloads
* *Compliance:* Built-in time-based and legal hold retention policies
* *Scalability:* Unlimited storage capacity for long-term audit retention
* *Integration:* Better support for external SIEM and compliance tools

h4. 2.3.3 Storage Configuration Management

* *Install-time Parameters:* Azure storage account name, container name, access keys configured during installation
* *Runtime Configuration:* Storage parameters modifiable via:
** Command-line interface with administrative authentication
** REST API endpoint with administrator role authorization
** Configuration changes logged as administrative audit events
* *Validation:* Connection testing required before applying new storage configuration

h3. 2.4 Data Transmission

* *Batch Transmission:* Audit events transmitted in configurable batch sizes (default: 100 events or 1MB)
* *Transmission Frequency:* Configurable interval (default: 5 minutes)
* *Retry Logic:* Failed transmissions retried with exponential backoff (max 24 hours)
* *Verification:* Receipt confirmation from Azure before local deletion
* *Network Security:* All transmissions use TLS 1.3 with certificate validation

h2. 3. Non-Functional Requirements

h3. 3.1 Performance

* *Event Capture:* < 10ms latency for audit event logging
* *Local Processing:* < 100ms for event encryption and local storage
* *Azure Transmission:* Batch transmission within 5 minutes of event capture
* *System Impact:* < 2% CPU overhead during normal operations
* *Storage Efficiency:* < 1KB average per encrypted log entry

h3. 3.2 Reliability

* *Event Capture:* 99.99% successful capture rate for audit events
* *Azure Transmission:* 99.9% successful transmission rate with retry logic
* *Local Storage:* Graceful degradation during Azure connectivity issues
* *Recovery:* Automatic resume of Azure transmission when connectivity restored

h3. 3.3 Security

* *Local Encryption:* AES-256 encryption for all local audit data
* *Transit Encryption:* TLS 1.3 for all Azure communications
* *Key Management:* Integration with Azure Key Vault for encryption keys
* *Access Control:* Administrative authentication required for configuration changes
* *Integrity:* Cryptographic signing of audit events before transmission

h3. 3.4 Configuration Management

* *Parameter Storage:* Secure storage of Azure connection parameters
* *Runtime Updates:* Hot-swapping of storage configuration without service restart
* *Validation:* Pre-deployment testing of Azure connectivity and permissions
* *Documentation:* All configuration changes logged with administrator identity

h2. 4. Technical Specifications

h3. 4.1 Integration Points

* *Atlas Authentication Service:* User login/logout events
* *Atlas Authorization Service:* Permission and role changes
* *Atlas Data Layer:* Content access and modifications
* *Atlas API Gateway:* External system interactions
* *Cleansheet Identity Provider:* Cross-platform user activities

h3. 4.2 Azure Storage Implementation

* *Primary Storage:* Azure Blob Storage (General Purpose v2)
* *Container Structure:* Hierarchical naming by date and event type
{noformat}audit-logs/
├── YYYY/MM/DD/
│   ├── authentication/
│   ├── authorization/
│   ├── data_access/
│   ├── administrative/
│   └── integration/{noformat}
* *Blob Format:* JSON Lines (.jsonl) with GZIP compression
* *Immutable Policy:* Time-based retention with minimum 7-year hold
* *Access Tier:* Hot tier for recent data, Cool tier for archive

h3. 4.3 Local Architecture

* *Storage Engine:* SQLite with WAL mode for local queuing
* *Encryption Library:* Azure Key Vault integrated encryption
* *Transmission Service:* Background service with configurable intervals
* *Configuration Store:* Encrypted configuration file with admin-only access

h3. 4.4 Configuration Parameters

{code:json}{
  "azureStorage": {
    "accountName": "configurable_at_install",
    "containerName": "atlas-audit-logs",
    "accessKey": "encrypted_storage_key",
    "connectionString": "computed_from_account_and_key"
  },
  "transmission": {
    "batchSize": 100,
    "intervalMinutes": 5,
    "maxRetryHours": 24,
    "compressionEnabled": true
  },
  "localStorage": {
    "maxRetentionHours": 48,
    "encryptionKeyId": "azure_key_vault_key_id",
    "queueLocation": "local_encrypted_database_path"
  }
}{code}

h3. 4.5 Administrative API Endpoints

* *GET /api/admin/audit/config* - Retrieve current configuration (keys masked)
* *PUT /api/admin/audit/config* - Update Azure storage parameters
* *POST /api/admin/audit/test-connection* - Validate Azure connectivity
* *GET /api/admin/audit/status* - Check transmission queue status
* *POST /api/admin/audit/flush* - Force immediate transmission of queued events

h2. 5. Implementation Phases

h3. Phase 1: Local Collection Infrastructure (Weeks 1-4)

* Implement audit event capture framework within Atlas components
* Set up local encrypted storage with SQLite
* Develop Azure Key Vault integration for encryption keys
* Create basic configuration management system

h3. Phase 2: Azure Integration (Weeks 5-8)

* Implement Azure Blob Storage transmission service
* Configure immutable storage policies and container structure
* Develop retry logic and connection testing
* Implement administrative API endpoints for configuration

h3. Phase 3: Production Hardening (Weeks 9-12)

* Complete integration with all Atlas authentication/authorization services
* Performance testing and optimization under load
* Security validation and penetration testing
* Documentation and deployment procedures

h2. 6. Success Criteria

h3. 6.1 Functional Success

* *Event Capture:* 100% capture rate for all defined audit event types
* *Azure Transmission:* 99.9% successful transmission rate within SLA timeframes
* *Local Storage Management:* Zero local audit data retention beyond Azure transmission confirmation
* *Configuration Management:* All Azure storage parameters configurable via CLI and API

h3. 6.2 Operational Success

* *Data Integrity:* Zero data loss during normal operations and Azure connectivity issues
* *Performance Impact:* < 2% system overhead during peak usage periods
* *Recovery:* Automatic resume of operations within 5 minutes of Azure connectivity restoration
* *Administration:* Configuration changes completed without service interruption

h3. 6.3 Security and Compliance Success

* *Encryption:* All audit data encrypted locally and in transit with verified key management
* *Immutability:* Azure Blob Storage configured with immutable retention policies
* *Access Control:* Administrative functions protected with proper authentication
* *Audit Trail:* All configuration changes and administrative actions logged

h2. 7. Risks and Mitigations

h3. 7.1 Azure Connectivity Risk

* *Risk:* Extended Azure Storage unavailability causes local storage overflow
* *Mitigation:* 48-hour local buffer capacity with overflow alerting

h3. 7.2 Encryption Key Management Risk

* *Risk:* Azure Key Vault unavailability prevents audit logging
* *Mitigation:* Local key caching with secure fallback encryption methods

h3. 7.3 Configuration Security Risk

* *Risk:* Unauthorized modification of Azure storage parameters
* *Mitigation:* Strong administrative authentication with audit logging of all changes

h3. 7.4 Performance Degradation Risk

* *Risk:* High-frequency audit events impact Atlas platform responsiveness
* *Mitigation:* Asynchronous processing with configurable batching and local queuing

h2. 8. Acceptance Criteria

h3. 8.1 Minimum Viable Product

* [ ] All defined audit event types captured with < 10ms latency
* [ ] Local encrypted storage operational with immediate deletion post-transmission
* [ ] Azure Blob Storage transmission functional with retry logic
* [ ] Administrative API endpoints operational for configuration management
* [ ] Azure storage parameters configurable via CLI and API

h3. 8.2 Production Readiness

* [ ] Performance requirements met: < 2% system overhead under normal load
* [ ] Security validation: End-to-end encryption verified with penetration testing
* [ ] Azure immutable storage policies configured and tested
* [ ] Extended Azure connectivity failure handled gracefully (48-hour local buffer)
* [ ] Administrative procedures documented for storage configuration management
* [ ] All configuration changes properly audited and logged

The current mathematic authoring workflow is too fractured to be very useful for depth work.  Before we launch for preview, we should fix it.  

We have a few options:

# Remove the dedicated KaTeX editor and render LaTex written in the MarkedJS renderer
# Replace the LaTeX renderer to an alternative renderer that can handle full documents
# Remove the LaTeX renderer until we can do (1) or (2).

We should implement the most expedient solution, but we will probably want to add a full document renderer at some point in the future.



Ideally, we would render full latex (TEX) docs.

Files to Remove Before Merge

🗂️ Extraneous Business Files:

* AtlasKickstarter.xlsx (52KB business planning file)
* sim.zip (294KB - unknown simulation files)
* tos.md (standalone terms of service - redundant with Cleansheet)

📚 Redundant Documentation:

* Root /README.md (will conflict with Cleansheet README)
* /api/README.md (outdated, replace with integrated docs)
* /web/README.md (outdated, replace with integrated docs)
* All runbook files in /api/runbook/ (audit-log, telemetry - move to ops docs)
* /web/documentations/ directory (outdated development docs)

🧪 Test/Sample Data:

* /img/exampleMap.png

🔧 Build/Development Artifacts:

column27: As a product planner, I would like a running inventory of enhancements that are required or recommended by the developers for the platform to perform reliably at scale.    This should be entered into the backlog and prioritized as issues emerge.

As an administrator, I would like the ability to configure the SMTP service leveraged by the platform for OTP and potential future uses (such as welcome emails, etc).  Parameters should include:

* SMTP Host Server
* Port
* Encryption Options (TLS/SSL)
* Username
* password
* From address
* From Name

The subject line should be prepended by the %PlatformName% as set by the user, for example:

* Cleansheet:  Your One-Time Passcode

As a platform administrator, I require the ability to view key performance metrics in the platform so that I can observe and mitigate infrastructure performance and capacity issues.

Current Utilization:

* Disk Space (GiB total, % used)
* Memory Space (GiB total, % used)
* CPU Average (% utilization)

Historical (14 days running)

* CPU Utilization (%)
* Memory Utilization (GiB)
* Disk I/O (KiB)
** read
** write
* Network I/O (KiB)
** received
** sent

Framework should be as simple and lightweight as possible.  Robust solutions such as promethues and grafana are robust, but may be overkill for this app.

As a product planner, I would like a roadmap for testing the fundamental unique functionality of the platform, including *but not limited to*:

# User onboarding workflows
# Account setting change workflows
# Structure backup/restore workflows
# Structure export workflows

Test automation should be driven by a repository of test data resident in the platform repo populated by exports from existing iterations of the platform.

As a product planner, I need a transparent self-assessment of the platform in preparation for formal pen-testing.  This assessment should include a prioritized roadmap of tools, processes, and changes that may be required to mitigate challenges faced in penetration testing.
Features impacting the platform install, and operational experience
Features impacting the end user experience
Features and capabilities impacting the administrator experience

* issues materially impacting user experience (reliable SNS, etc)
* elements impacting scale (assuming 50 simultaneous users, 500 total per instance)
* issues likely to arise during penetration testing
* issues impacting ability to functionally troubleshoot platform

Drop in replacement of Quill with hugeRTE. 

[hugerte/hugerte: MIT-licensed fork of TinyMCE, the world's #1 JavaScript library for rich text editing, which switched from MIT to a GPL-or-pay license model in its latest version.|https://github.com/hugerte/hugerte]

Modal for Password reset.  SMTP to OTP to the user’s email to change the password.  Triggered from:

* Individual User Settings Modal
* Login page

Add following capabilities to User Settings (in addition to API key management)

* Change their display name
* Trigger Password Reset

As a product planner, I require an accurate inventory of technical debt, so that I can assess the platform’s suitability for safe application to use cases and environments.

* issues materially impacting user experience (reliable SNS, etc)
* elements impacting scale (assuming 50 simultaneous users, 500 total per instance)
* issues likely to arise during penetration testing
* issues impacting ability to functionally troubleshoot platform

h2. Example use case: Laptop

h3. System Description

A business laptop computer system that fails when it cannot perform basic computing tasks. The system includes:

* 3 critical subsystems that ALL must function (CPU, Memory, Storage)
* 2 redundant power sources (battery OR AC adapter)
* 2 cooling fans (any 1 of 2 sufficient for cooling)
* 3 USB ports (any 2 of 3 must work for peripheral connectivity)

h3. Fault Tree Structure

{noformat}                    LAPTOP COMPUTER SYSTEM FAILS
                              (TOP EVENT)
                                   |
                              [OR GATE]
                                   |
        ┌───────────────┬──────────┼──────────┬───────────────┐
        |               |          |          |               |
   CPU FAILS     MEMORY FAILS  STORAGE    POWER FAILS    COOLING FAILS
                              FAILS      (AND GATE)      (VOTE 2/2)
                                             |               |
                                        [AND GATE]      [VOTE 2/2]
                                             |               |
                                      ┌──────┼──────┐   ┌─────┼─────┐
                                      |             |   |           |
                                 BATTERY        AC ADAPTER  FAN-1   FAN-2
                                  FAILS          FAILS      FAILS   FAILS
                                                                    
                              USB CONNECTIVITY FAILS
                                (VOTE 2/3)
                                    |
                               [VOTE 2/3]
                                    |
                            ┌───────┼───────┐
                            |       |       |
                         USB-1   USB-2   USB-3
                         FAILS   FAILS   FAILS
{noformat}

h3. Basic Event Data

||Component||Parent Gate||Gate Type||Vote Values (k/n)||Failure Rate (λ)||Mission Time (t)||MTTR||Basic Probability||
|CPU|TOP EVENT|OR|N/A|2.0E-6 /hr|8760 hr/yr|4 hr|1.75E-2|
|MEMORY|TOP EVENT|OR|N/A|5.0E-6 /hr|8760 hr/yr|2 hr|4.36E-2|
|STORAGE|TOP EVENT|OR|N/A|1.0E-5 /hr|8760 hr/yr|8 hr|8.76E-2|
|BATTERY|POWER FAILS|AND|N/A|3.0E-5 /hr|8760 hr/yr|1 hr|2.29E-1|
|AC-ADAPTER|POWER FAILS|AND|N/A|1.0E-5 /hr|8760 hr/yr|24 hr|8.76E-2|
|FAN-1|COOLING FAILS|VOTE|2/2|8.0E-6 /hr|8760 hr/yr|6 hr|6.84E-2|
|FAN-2|COOLING FAILS|VOTE|2/2|8.0E-6 /hr|8760 hr/yr|6 hr|6.84E-2|
|USB-1|USB FAILS|VOTE|2/3|2.0E-5 /hr|8760 hr/yr|2 hr|1.61E-1|
|USB-2|USB FAILS|VOTE|2/3|2.0E-5 /hr|8760 hr/yr|2 hr|1.61E-1|
|USB-3|USB FAILS|VOTE|2/3|2.0E-5 /hr|8760 hr/yr|2 hr|1.61E-1|

_Basic Probability Calculation: P = 1 - e^(-λt) for time-based failures_

Gather/communicate top level design guidance for Syncfusion renderer front end

* Structure Display State Persistent
** stored with .enc file on backup/export
** stored between sessions
* User-defined states
** Users can save, update (in the future, share) display states
* Structure Order
** Tight control - only deliberate actions by the user to re-order 
** Visual Feedback on re-ordering within a level
* Single action menu
** All actions driven from a single menu
** Minimize context menu icons
* WBS
** Toggleable
** User override of root integer
* User-defined Customization
** Word wrap/truncation
** Color lock at level
** Collapse/expand to level
*  Behavior
** Strong visual feedback on reparenting
** Visual indication of presence of a record
* Actions 
** Move Edit Element action to Edit Record Model
** Move Delete Record action to Edit Record Modal
** Combine Add/Edit Record action

User control over element display order is very important for some of our early use cases.  This ticket provides discrete and predictable control over element ordering in the display and export.

Element ordering behavior

* When creating an element, it is placed last in the list of its peers 
* When re-parenting an element, it is placed last in the list of its peers
* Element Record and tag CRUD does not impact the display order of the element.

Right now, undo has unpredictable behavior when an element has been deleted.  An undo will appear to restore the element, but when you add a record to the element, the system errors out.  Let’s just remove it for now, then we can clearly define behavior upon reimplementation.
As a user I would like the entire displayed state of the syncfusion  to be preserved between sessions, including logout.

As a Structure Owner, 

* I would like to leverage Stucture Settings (ATL-39) to redirect large objects associated with individual Structures to an external S3 bucket of my designation, so that I can control infrastructure costs, while maintaining the ability to strictly segregate data
* I would like to be able to assign a default S3 bucket in my Account Settings (ATL-44), so that new structures I create can leverage the bucket of my designation
* I would like the Structure Inventory (ATL-14) to support bulk re-direction of multiple Structures to an S3 bucket of my designation

As a structure owner, I would like the ability to perform snapshots of my structures.  Snapshots should be listed in a tabular inventory in the Structure Settings interface. (ATL-39).

On Snapshot restore, I should be able to restore to the originating structure or to a newly created structure.

As an academic user, I would like the ability to perform CRUDS on Sage models on the Atlas platform, and associate them with elements.

[concord-consortium/sage-modeler-site|https://github.com/concord-consortium/sage-modeler-site]
As a structure owner, I require a simple tabular interface associated with the structure, so that I can coordinate and track the activities among the multiple contributors.

As a developer, I would like to leverage a simplified version of vscode to function as a record editor for renderers and compilers such as markedjs and plantUML, mermaid, LaTeX.

Each record would leverage either the Quill editor or the vscode editor.  When the user switches between Quill and vscode, they will be prompted that the existing record data will be deleted.

[coder/code-server: VS Code in the browser|https://github.com/coder/code-server]

implementation should be simplified to the context of the renderer/compiler.  for this release it will be limited to the markedjs compiler.  In the future, the user will be able to choose LaTeX, PlantUML, etc as well.

Miro does this well.  Features they offer are limited to:

# Editing
# Line numbering
# Search/Replace
# Linting

As a document editor, I would like to be able to leverage a simple markdown editor, so that I can work in a familiar environment on the Atlas platform.  

[markedjs/marked: A markdown parser and compiler. Built for speed.|https://github.com/markedjs/marked?tab=readme-ov-file]

[Marked Demo|https://marked.js.org/demo/?text=Marked%20-%20Markdown%20Parser%0A%3D%3D%3D%3D%3D%3D%3D%3D%3D%3D%3D%3D%3D%3D%3D%3D%3D%3D%3D%3D%3D%3D%3D%3D%0A%0A%5BMarked%5D%20lets%20you%20convert%20%5BMarkdown%5D%20into%20HTML.%20%20Markdown%20is%20a%20simple%20text%20format%20whose%20goal%20is%20to%20be%20very%20easy%20to%20read%20and%20write%2C%20even%20when%20not%20converted%20to%20HTML.%20%20This%20demo%20page%20will%20let%20you%20type%20anything%20you%20like%20and%20see%20how%20it%20gets%20converted.%20%20Live.%20%20No%20more%20waiting%20around.%0A%0AHow%20To%20Use%20The%20Demo%0A-------------------%0A%0A1.%20Type%20in%20stuff%20on%20the%20left.%0A2.%20See%20the%20live%20updates%20on%20the%20right.%0A%0AThat%27s%20it.%20%20Pretty%20simple.%20%20There%27s%20also%20a%20drop-down%20option%20above%20to%20switch%20between%20various%20views%3A%0A%0A-%20**Preview%3A**%20%20A%20live%20display%20of%20the%20generated%20HTML%20as%20it%20would%20render%20in%20a%20browser.%0A-%20**HTML%20Source%3A**%20%20The%20generated%20HTML%20before%20your%20browser%20makes%20it%20pretty.%0A-%20**Lexer%20Data%3A**%20%20What%20%5Bmarked%5D%20uses%20internally%2C%20in%20case%20you%20like%20gory%20stuff%20like%20this.%0A-%20**Quick%20Reference%3A**%20%20A%20brief%20run-down%20of%20how%20to%20format%20things%20using%20markdown.%0A%0AWhy%20Markdown%3F%0A-------------%0A%0AIt%27s%20easy.%20%20It%27s%20not%20overly%20bloated%2C%20unlike%20HTML.%20%20Also%2C%20as%20the%20creator%20of%20%5Bmarkdown%5D%20says%2C%0A%0A%3E%20The%20overriding%20design%20goal%20for%20Markdown%27s%0A%3E%20formatting%20syntax%20is%20to%20make%20it%20as%20readable%0A%3E%20as%20possible.%20The%20idea%20is%20that%20a%0A%3E%20Markdown-formatted%20document%20should%20be%0A%3E%20publishable%20as-is%2C%20as%20plain%20text%2C%20without%0A%3E%20looking%20like%20it%27s%20been%20marked%20up%20with%20tags%0A%3E%20or%20formatting%20instructions.%0A%0AReady%20to%20start%20writing%3F%20%20Either%20start%20changing%20stuff%20on%20the%20left%20or%0A%5Bclear%20everything%5D(%2Fdemo%2F%3Ftext%3D)%20with%20a%20simple%20click.%0A%0A%5BMarked%5D%3A%20https%3A%2F%2Fgithub.com%2Fmarkedjs%2Fmarked%2F%0A%5BMarkdown%5D%3A%20http%3A%2F%2Fdaringfireball.net%2Fprojects%2Fmarkdown%2F%0A&options=%7B%0A%20%22async%22%3A%20false%2C%0A%20%22breaks%22%3A%20false%2C%0A%20%22extensions%22%3A%20null%2C%0A%20%22gfm%22%3A%20true%2C%0A%20%22hooks%22%3A%20null%2C%0A%20%22pedantic%22%3A%20false%2C%0A%20%22silent%22%3A%20false%2C%0A%20%22tokenizer%22%3A%20null%2C%0A%20%22walkTokens%22%3A%20null%0A%7D&version=15.0.8]

As a structure author, 

* I would like to create tooltips in simple markdown format, so that I can communicate context about the structure element to the user.
* I would like to import and export tooltips from the AtlasKickstarter and Atlas Backup data formats, so that I can perform bulk tooltip CRUD.

Would like to explore the idea of implementing this as a “system tag” or “platform tag” rather than a schema change.  I feel like there may be a number of use cases for these types of tags, some of them specific to each use case.  I believe this approach may simplify our data model.
